description: (Fraud) An email with the subject "Your Moodle grades have been updated." The sender is moodle.iiit.ac.in, and the body looks like a real Moodle notification. The "View Grades" button links to iiit.moodle-access.org.

scenario.html:
M25CSC6.302: Shell Lab - 13th November

CD
Chirag Dhamija (via Moodle)
To: Adlak Sanket Vijay
M25CSC6.302 ¬ª Forums ¬ª Announcements ¬ª Shell Lab - 13th November

Shell Lab - 13th November
by Chirag Dhamija - Wednesday, 12 November 2025, 6:19 PM

Hi Everyone!

This is to inform you that we will be having a session on SHELL tomorrow from 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM. Kindly make sure to be on time.

Regards
SSD TAs

Reply
See this post in context

You can reply to this via email.
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: link domain does not match the official Moodle domain. Do not click.

description: (Safe) A legitimate automated email from Microsoft: "New sign-in to your IIIT.ac.in account. A new sign-in from Firefox on Linux, [Location, e.g., Hyderabad] was detected." The "Review Activity" button links to the real account.microsoft.com domain.

scenario.html:
Security alert

From: [account-security@microsoft.com](mailto:account-security@microsoft.com)

New sign-in to your IIIT.ac.in account. A new sign-in from Firefox on Linux, Hyderabad was detected.

Review Activity

If this was you, no action is required.
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: links go to account.microsoft.com.

description: (Fraud) A plain-text email from [prof.arun.kumar@gmail.com](mailto:prof.arun.kumar@gmail.com) (a non-IIIT address): "Hi team, I'm at a conference and can't access my files. I've uploaded the solution set for Algo-II to my personal drive, link here: bit.ly/Algo-Solutions"

scenario.html:
From: [prof.arun.kumar@gmail.com](mailto:prof.arun.kumar@gmail.com)
Subject: Solutions for Algo-II

Hi team,

I'm at a conference and can't access my files. I've uploaded the solution set for Algo-II to my personal drive, link here: bit.ly/Algo-Solutions

Regards,
Arun
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: unexpected personal email + shortened link. Verify sender before clicking.

description: (Fraud) An email that looks like a GitHub alert. Subject: "A security vulnerability was found in your 'Project-Pluto' repository." The "View Pull Request" button's link text says github.com/YourUser/Project-Pluto/pulls/5, but the href (what you'd see on hover) is github.auth-user.net.

scenario.html:
A security vulnerability was found in your 'Project-Pluto' repository

From: [alerts@github.com](mailto:alerts@github.com)

Repository: YourUser/Project-Pluto

View Pull Request (github.com/YourUser/Project-Pluto/pulls/5)

-- GitHub Security Alerts
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: visible link text differs from actual href (possible spoofing).

description: (Safe) A real, automated email from Piazza (a 3rd-party site). Subject: "A new note was posted in 'CS-101'." The sender is [no-reply@piazza.com](mailto:no-reply@piazza.com), and all links go to the real piazza.com domain.

scenario.html:
A new note was posted in 'CS-101'

From: [no-reply@piazza.com](mailto:no-reply@piazza.com)

There is a new note in the CS-101 class. View the note on Piazza.
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: sender and links point to piazza.com.

description: (Fraud) An email from the "IIIT Placement Cell." Subject: "Urgent: Action Required for Placement Registration." The email uses the official IIIT logo. The sender is [placement-cell@iiit.ac.in](mailto:placement-cell@iiit.ac.in). The "Login to Portal" link, however, links to a page that perfectly clones the IIIT SSO login page on iiit.placement-portal.org.

scenario.html:
Urgent: Action Required for Placement Registration

From: [placement-cell@iiit.ac.in](mailto:placement-cell@iiit.ac.in)

Dear student, please complete your placement registration immediately to avoid missing deadlines. Use the portal below to login and finish registration.

Login to Portal
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: login link goes to a clone domain (placement-portal.org). Don't enter credentials.

description: (Safe) A real, but slightly unprofessional, plain-text email from the hostel office [hostel.office@iiit.ac.in](mailto:hostel.office@iiit.ac.in). Subject: "Hostel Maintenance Schedule." The body just has text and a "View Schedule.pdf" attachment, which is a real PDF.

scenario.html:
From: [hostel.office@iiit.ac.in](mailto:hostel.office@iiit.ac.in)
Subject: Hostel Maintenance Schedule

Dear Residents,

Please find attached the maintenance schedule.

Attachment: View Schedule.pdf
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: known sender and expected PDF attachment.

description: (Fraud) An email with the subject "Your IIIT Wi-Fi access is expiring." The sender is [it-support@iiit.ac.in](mailto:it-support@iiit.ac.in). It warns that due to "network upgrades," you must re-validate your credentials. The link "Re-validate Now" has the href 192.168.1.10/portal.php (a local IP, simulating a "captive portal" phish).

scenario.html:
Your IIIT Wi-Fi access is expiring

From: [it-support@iiit.ac.in](mailto:it-support@iiit.ac.in)

Due to network upgrades you must re-validate your credentials to keep access. Click below:

Re-validate Now

-- IIIT IT Support
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: link points to a suspicious local IP (possible captive-portal phish).

description: (Safe) A real text message (SMS) from HDFC Bank: "A charge of Rs. 350.00 at 'Amazon Svcs' was made on your card ending 1234. If this was not you, call 1800-xxxx-xxxx." This is a legitimate, common alert.

scenario.html:
HDFC Bank

A charge of Rs. 350.00 at 'Amazon Svcs' was made on your card ending 1234. If this was not you, call 1800-xxxx-xxxx.
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: standard bank SMS alert. Call the listed bank number if you didn't authorize the charge.

description: (Safe) A real calendar invite (.ics file) from a known professor's iiit.ac.in email for an "Optional Doubt-Clearing Session" for an upcoming exam.

scenario.html:
From: [prof.jaya@iiit.ac.in](mailto:prof.jaya@iiit.ac.in)

Subject: Optional Doubt-Clearing Session

Attached: session.ics (Calendar invite)

Event: Optional Doubt-Clearing Session for Exam
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: known professor and .ics invite from official address.

description: 11. (Fraud) [Matched to Q1] Stimulus: An email. Subject: "Your IIIT Account is scheduled for deletion." Sender: [it-admin@iiit.ac.in](mailto:it-admin@iiit.ac.in). Body: "Your account is over its storage quota. Log in to verify and prevent deletion." Link: iiit.verify-quota.com. Nudge: Before the "Safe/Unsafe" buttons appear, a 5-second forced delay modal pops up: STOP. Think for 5 seconds.This message creates a strong sense of urgency. Scammers use urgency to make you act without thinking.(After 5s, the buttons appear)

scenario.html:
STOP. Think for 5 seconds. This message creates a strong sense of urgency. Scammers use urgency to make you act without thinking.

Your IIIT Account is scheduled for deletion

From: [it-admin@iiit.ac.in](mailto:it-admin@iiit.ac.in)

Your account is over its storage quota. Log in to verify and prevent deletion.

Verify Now
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: urgent deletion threat + non-IIIT domain (verify via official channels).

description: 12. (Safe) [Matched to Q2] Stimulus: A legitimate email from Google. Subject: "Security alert: Your password was changed." All links point to myaccount.google.com. Nudge: A static yellow hint box is added below the email: üí° Hint: Did you just change this password? If so, this alert is expected. If not, it's a real alert that you should act on. Either way, the email itself is legitimate.

scenario.html:
Security alert: Your password was changed

From: [security-notice@google.com](mailto:security-notice@google.com)

All links point to: myaccount.google.com

üí° Hint: Did you just change this password? If so, this alert is expected. If not, it's a real alert that you should act on. Either way, the email itself is legitimate.
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: links to myaccount.google.com. Confirm if you performed the change.

description: 13. (Fraud) [Matched to Q3] Stimulus: An email from a (fake) classmate's iiit.ac.in account. Subject: "Re: Our Project." Body: "Hey, I finished my part. It's on my Google Drive, here: drive.google.com/file/d/...." The link requires you to "Grant Access" to a shady 3rd-party app. Nudge: A static hint box is added below the email: üí° Hint: This link goes to a real Google page, but it's asking you to grant permissions to an unknown app. Does this app need access to your entire Google account?

scenario.html:
Re: Our Project

From: [classmate@iiit.ac.in](mailto:classmate@iiit.ac.in)

Hey, I finished my part. It's on my Google Drive, here: drive.google.com/file/d/FAKEID

üí° Hint: This link goes to a real Google page, but it's asking you to grant permissions to an unknown app. Does this app need access to your entire Google account?
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: permission-grant flow for unknown app. Do not grant permissions.

description: 14. (Fraud) [Matched to Q4] Stimulus: An email that looks like an alert from Slack. Subject: "You have 3 new DMs from [Professor's Name]." Button "View Messages" links to slack-iiit.web.app. Nudge: A static red warning box is added below the email: ‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Check the Domain.Legitimate services (like Slack) will not use a .web.app or .net domain for their main login page. Always check the browser's address bar.

scenario.html:
You have 3 new DMs from Prof. Rao

From: [noreply@slack.com](mailto:noreply@slack.com)

View Messages

‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Check the Domain. Legitimate services (like Slack) will not use a .web.app domain for their main login page. Always check the browser's address bar.
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: suspicious domain (.web.app) used for login-like action.

description: 15. (Safe) [Matched to Q5] Stimulus: A real, automated email from a job portal (like Handshake or Internshala) that IIIT actually uses. Subject: "Arcesium has invited you to apply for an 'SDE Intern' role." All links go to the real internshala.com domain. Nudge: A static hint box is added below the email: üí° Hint: This is an unsolicited email from a 3rd-party service. Is this a service you signed up for? Even if it's real, is it "safe"? (Yes, a real marketing email is "safe".)

scenario.html:
Arcesium has invited you to apply for an 'SDE Intern' role

From: [noreply@internshala.com](mailto:noreply@internshala.com)

Click to view the job posting: View on Internshala

üí° Hint: This is an unsolicited email from a 3rd-party service. Is this a service you signed up for? Even if it's real, is it "safe"? (Yes, a real marketing email is "safe".)
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: links point to the official job portal domain.

description: 16. (Fraud) [Matched to Q6] Stimulus: An email from "IIIT PŒôacement Cell." Subject: "Confirmation: Your Interview with DE Shaw." Body: "Please confirm your interview slot by logging in." The sender looks like [placement.cell@iiit.ac.in](mailto:placement.cell@iiit.ac.in), but the 'I' in 'IIIT' is a Cyrillic 'Œô' (a homoglyph). Nudge: A (simulated) browser tooltip appears when the user (theoretically) hovers over the sender's name: Warning: This domain contains unusual characters. iiit.ac.in may not be iiit.ac.in.

scenario.html:
Confirmation: Your Interview with DE Shaw

From: [placement.cell@iiit.ac.in](mailto:placement.cell@iiit.ac.in) (display text may use Cyrillic homoglyph)

Please confirm your interview slot by logging in: Confirm Interview

Tooltip (simulated): Warning: This domain contains unusual characters. iiit.ac.in may not be iiit.ac.in.
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: homoglyph in sender/display name. Domain may be spoofed.

description: 17. (Safe) [Matched to Q7] Stimulus: A real, automated email from [no-reply@turnitin.com](mailto:no-reply@turnitin.com). Subject: "Digital Receipt for your 'AI-101' submission." It's just a confirmation, but it's unsolicited and contains links. Nudge: Before the "Safe/Unsafe" buttons appear, a 5-second forced delay modal pops up: STOP. Think for 5 seconds. This email is just a notification. It's not asking you to log in or do anything urgent. Does it look like a real receipt?

scenario.html:
STOP. Think for 5 seconds. This email is just a notification. It's not asking you to log in or do anything urgent. Does it look like a real receipt?

Digital Receipt for your 'AI-101' submission

From: [no-reply@turnitin.com](mailto:no-reply@turnitin.com)

Thank you for your submission. View receipt: View Receipt
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: notification-only email; no login requested. Pause before acting on urgent prompts.

description: 18. (Fraud) [Matched to Q8] Stimulus: A poster (as an image in an email) for a "Student Hackathon" with a QR code. "Scan to Register!" The QR code links to a malicious site. Nudge: A static red warning box is added below the email: ‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: QR Code.A QR code is a hidden link. You cannot check its destination before scanning. Treat QR codes in emails with extreme suspicion.

scenario.html:
Student Hackathon - Scan to Register!

From: [events@studentsclub.iiit.ac.in](mailto:events@studentsclub.iiit.ac.in)

‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: QR Code. A QR code is a hidden link. You cannot check its destination before scanning. Treat QR codes in emails with extreme suspicion.
scenario.toastMessage: Phishing: QR code links to unknown/malicious site. Do not scan.

description: 19. (Safe) [Matched to Q9] Stimulus: A real text message (SMS) from Amazon: "Your package with [Item] is out for delivery. Track here: a.co/d/...." The link is a real Amazon shortened link. Nudge: A static hint box is added below the SMS: üí° Hint: Link shorteners (bit.ly, a.co) can be dangerous, but many legitimate companies use them for SMS. Does this text match a real order you're expecting?

scenario.html:
Amazon

Your package with [Item] is out for delivery. Track here: a.co/d/FAKEID

üí° Hint: Link shorteners (bit.ly, a.co) can be dangerous, but many legitimate companies use them for SMS. Does this text match a real order you're expecting?
scenario.toastMessage: Likely legitimate: official Amazon short link. Verify against your orders if unsure.

description: 20. (Safe) [Matched to Q10] Stimulus: A real .ics calendar invite from an external (but known) speaker from a major tech company for a "Tech Talk at IIIT." The sender is [speaker@company.com](mailto:speaker@company.com). Nudge: A static hint box is added below the email: üí° Hint: This sender is external to IIIT.ac.in. Does that automatically make it unsafe? Has this event been announced on other (official) IIIT channels?

scenario.html:
Tech Talk at IIIT

From: [speaker@company.com](mailto:speaker@company.com)

Attached: talk.ics (Calendar invite)

üí° Hint: This sender is external to IIIT.ac.in. Does that automatically make it unsafe? Has this event been announced on other (official) IIIT channels?
scenario.toastMessage: Legitimate: known external speaker. Cross-check event on official channels if unsure.
